title: Interviews: Mister Sandman
historical_context: This interview captures the early days of virus writing and the hacker culture in the mid-1990s, a time when personal computing was becoming more widespread and the internet was beginning to connect enthusiasts globally.
target_audience: Hackers, virus writers, security professionals, and those interested in hacker culture.
short_summary: This article features an interview with b0z0, a young virus writer, discussing his early experiences with computing, virus coding, and the hacker scene. It provides insights into the motivations and thoughts of emerging talents in the virus writing community.
summary:
In this engaging interview, b0z0 shares his journey into the world of computing, starting with his early experiences on a ZX Spectrum and his initial encounters with computer viruses. He reflects on the simplicity of the viruses he has coded and expresses a growing interest in developing more sophisticated malware. The conversation reveals his thoughts on the virus writing community, the evolution of viruses, and the potential for future developments in malware technology. b0z0 also discusses the importance of collaboration within his group, iKx, which encompasses hackers, phreakers, and virus writers, emphasizing the exchange of knowledge and creativity among its members.

The interview also touches on the relationship between virus writers and antivirus software, with b0z0 expressing skepticism about the effectiveness of many antivirus products. He critiques the commercialization of antivirus solutions and highlights the value of smaller, individual-developed tools. Overall, this article provides a snapshot of the mindset of a young hacker during a pivotal time in the evolution of computer security and malware, making it a relevant read for anyone interested in the history and culture of hacking.
